bibl.title: Letter from E. J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1922

div1.p: Scannell reminisces about times he and Carter spent in Panama. He reports on yellow fever field work in Mexico and claims to have created a “no man's land” between Mexico and Guatemala.

div1.head: Letter from E. J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1922
div1.opener:
Tapachula,
Chiapas,
Mexico.
May 20, 1922.
I. H. B
Scannell
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon-General,
United States Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
I wish to thank you so much for the reprint which came yesterday
forwarded from New York - I had not seen the article before and no
doubt would have missed it entirely since I have nothing in way
of medical works except a few old fundamentals, in fact I have
been out of the world as it were for about four months now.
The work which you so well describe I can visualize and can well
understand the many problems with which you were confronted. Am
sorry I did not see some of the work first hand.

I do not like to think that your field service days are over
although I do think you have done more than your share already
toward the prevention of disease in the world, which in turn means
or spells greater happiness and prosperity for the human family.
We, of the old Panama days still think of Doctor Carter as our
Chief and when we fore-gather, in spirit we are back at Panama
wondering what Doctor Carter is going to do next - always fair
and just is the verdict of all who ever served under him.

I have been here now some three months without seeing a case of
yellow fever however have gone ahead and created a no mans land
between Guatemala and Mexico - all travel to and from Guatemala
passes through Tapachula, am enclosing a rough sketch to show the
key points - Tapachula controls Central America overland, Tonala
2.
and Jalisco control the interior of the state - all travel from the
interior passes through Jalisco except a few pack trains now and
then over very poor trails (three or four day trips) into Tabasco.
The average house index along the coast here was about 20 during
the dry weather but as soon as the rains began in April it increased
considerably - Tapachula showed about 20 per cent index and a rather
unusual feature here is the deep well breeding - I was told that
the deep wells need not be considered in the anti-stegomyia work
and that may hold true in many places but I find here that the wells
which run 20 to 30 feet deep are prolific breeders - it is a problem
also just how to care for them. I have been fishing all of them
although many are bound to die and affect the water which hardly
seems fair to the people involved however the people in Mexico
as a whole have been very nice to me and allow me to go ahead
and no questions asked.

Tapachula has a population of 10,000.
Elevation about 75 feet.
Temperature - no figures available but about the same as Panama
very hot (I assume Maximum about 100 Mean 80) with high degree
of humidity.

Water supply - from river through pipes but only a few houses
supplied, for most part people are supplied from fountains which
naturally calls for storage in the house, tinajas, ollas, barr
and the like being used.

Sewerage system- two streets only - a few have pit closets bt
but most consign their wastes to the calles or patios-
All along the coast here there is a history of “fiebre
perniciosa” it is described as a fiebre con hemorragias and
causes death within four to six days - last year Tapachula
had 110 deaths during month of May from above fiebre and that
3.
in a population of only 10,000.

There is no laboratory here and no facilities for doing research
work but clinically the chief diseases are malaria, hook-worm
and dysentery.

We started organizing about April 1st. and a little sketch enclosed
will show how the index has gradually dropped especially since I
got my fish started - am fishing all wells, tanks, barrels etc.
and find they as a rule they live readily although it is necessary to
use extreme care in handling them. The people watch their fish and
for the most part take good care of them.

We have 5 principal varieties of fish here - Pupos, Mojarritas and
Sardinas make three, the other two are not classified - one of the
unclassified being an especially good fish for our work feeding
both top and bottom. Shall send samples to the Board in hopes
the unknown may be definitely placed.

I have just recently returned from a trip into the interior to
Tuxtla also Chiapa de Corzo - at Tuxtla which by the way is a
very old town I found a house index of 67 per cent. the worst
thing I have seen in Mexico - their history shows Yellow fever
to have been present epidemic form in 1916 - nothing since has
been recognized as such.

I am satisfied that yellow fever is constantly being overlooked
in this section.

Let me again thank you for the reprint - it will help me in my
work I feel sure. Please commend me to your family and believe
me ever,
